title: Will an unmanned aerial vehicle be used by a non-governmental or intra-governmental organization to deliver humanitarian aid to a conflict zone in 2017?
preds: Adjusting down for the passage of time.
It seems logical to use unmanned drones to deliver food, water or water conversion kits to areas that might not permit outside personnel.
Maybe in 2018 when Windhorse Aero put their Pouncer drone into the air.
The idea may have been suggested, but has anyone actually tried it? I don't know how serious people are aboit it, or if they even have the ability to carry through with their idea.
At this point, it's unlikely to happen - only 10% chance that it's happened already and someone will post that information. Sad I didn't have time to make it happen.

How Drone Delivery Is Saving Lives in Rural Rwanda An innovative on-demand medical service in Rwanda is using drones to cut hours of delivery time into minutes, when every second counts. 
http://www.wsj.com/video/how-drone-delivery-is-saving-lives-in-rural-rwanda/665024AF-058F-4CB5-A1E1-C93BC67BAE3E.html?mod=trending_now_video_4

I don't see any news about it, and I think any company or org making this effort would be sure to publicize it ahead of time and make it clear that they need funding, donations etc., especially since this is such a hot topic in the news right now. That + the fact that it's already near years end makes it extremely unlikely that we will see an effort made this month.
I'm just going to say no at this point because there's only a month or so left in the year.

The World Food Programme, one of the first humanitarian organizations to explore the use of unmanned aerial vehicles back in 2007, hasn’t officially deployed any UAVs in responses this year. In fact, the agency’s drone count currently stands at zero. Instead, the United Nations food assistance branch has been putting drones in the sky only as part of a project to establish clearer guidelines for the humanitarian sector at large. “It’s something internally we agreed. We don’t have a guideline for using this new technology. There are a lot of questions around privacy, data protection, perceptions of the communities, accountability to affected populations … so we decided we are not going to deploy any until we sort this out and establish a practice,” said Haidar Baqir, information technology emergencies officer for the WFP’s Asia-Pacific Regional Bureau.
______________________
COMMENT:  Not anytime soon

A prototype for a disposable drone was developed, with designers claiming it could be ready for missions by the end of the year (so much for that-- it's currently in testing, and they're hoping for sometime in 2018). Their concept makes sense because no-one wants to risk expensive drones being shot down. I haven't seen anything like it elsewhere, so I'm adjusting down now that it's clear it won't be deployed by year's end. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-aid-innovation-drones/its-a-bird-its-a-plane-its-an-edible-aid-drone-idUSKBN15Z1TG
seems to me like a terrible idea, but maybe I don't understand what is a conflict zone.

Lowering significantly due to no news from Windhorse Aero on testing the Pouncer drone https://www.windhorse.aero/?jssCart=c0c1e11e0c8368de102ac986fd39d5ca, or any other companies testing drones in conflict zones. Therefore, lowering the likelihood that an NGO or IGO will use the technology in the next 7 weeks.

Comments: Groan..... no backbone. Adjusting accordingly.
Devex, November 6, 'Drone, meet the humanitarian cluster approach': https://www.devex.com/news/drone-meet-the-humanitarian-cluster-approach-91436
Clips from article:
"Instead, the United Nations food assistance branch has been putting drones in the sky only as part of a project to establish clearer guidelines for the humanitarian sector at large.
“It’s something internally we agreed. We don’t have a guideline for using this new technology. There are a lot of questions around privacy, data protection, perceptions of the communities, accountability to affected populations … so we decided we are not going to deploy any until we sort this out and establish a practice,” said Haidar Baqir, information technology emergencies officer for the WFP’s Asia-Pacific Regional Bureau."

Update December 2nd. Adjusting for time remaining, as well as links others have shared about drone aid. It looks like aid organizations are still ambivalent about the technology for aid to disaster areas, let alone combat zones. Even then, most of the applications are for mapping and info-gathering rather than delivery of materials.

https://www.devex.com/news/drone-meet-the-humanitarian-cluster-approach-91436 The World Food Programme, one of the first humanitarian organizations to explore the use of unmanned aerial vehicles back in 2007, hasn’t officially deployed any UAVs in responses this year. In fact, the agency’s drone count currently stands at zero.  Instead, the United Nations food assistance branch has been putting drones in the sky only as part of a project to establish clearer guidelines for the humanitarian sector at large. . . . . we decided we are not going to deploy any until we sort this out and establish a practice,” said Haidar Baqir, information technology emergencies officer for the WFP’s Asia-Pacific Regional Bureau. Several country-level communities of practice for the humanitarian use of drones already exist around the world, with nongovernmental organizations as partners to share the costs of flying drones and the data produced, often following a disaster. In Nepal, Tanzania, and Peru, “robotics for good” company WeRobotics has established “flying labs” to transfer relevant skills and technologies to local partners to incubate new drone businesses. The Belgian-funded WFP initiative that Baqir is heading up aims to collate those ideas to design solutions for the coordination of UAV use in the broader humanitarian community, addressing safety and data protection risks along the way. The result, Baqir hopes, will be an official partnership framework and accompanying code of conduct by early 2018 whereby drone deployment in emergencies will be managed by one humanitarian aid cluster in a transparent way. UAVs are increasingly being recognized by humanitarian organizations for their potential effectiveness in disaster response, helping teams safely observe situations in real-time during emergencies or quickly collect damage assessment information in remote areas. Drones can also provide “Wi-Fi in the sky” to get communities back online following a disaster, an idea the WFP has been experimenting with. At the same time, overuse or improper use of drones following disasters in the past few years have left many aid groups wondering how to move forward responsibly. Several organizations already exist to help educate people about best practices, such as WeRobotics — which is partnering with the WFP on the drone coordination initiative — and the Humanitarian UAV Network, both founded by humanitarian technology and innovation expert Patrick Meier. But the WFP project is the biggest effort on the international stage to professionalize drone coordination throughout the sector — and it can’t come soon enough, according to Meier.
. . . 
In the Philippines, drone company SkyEye has been providing aerial mapping and disaster response surveying services for several years. . . . Following a disaster, SkyEye might map affected schools for Save the Children. World Vision might overlay data on damage per house while the IOM surveys those who may have lost homes and will need to move into alternate housing.  . . .  The single biggest challenge to drone use for humanitarian aid remains local regulations that were usually created for commercial drone use, according to Meier, who saw this again recently in the South Pacific while piloting drones for the World Bank’s UAVs for Resilience program. . . .  Once standards and regulations have been set, it’s time to look closer at coordination, which is the biggest mandate of the WFP’s current project.  Ideally, Baqir said, drones would live under the Emergency Telecommunications Cluster, which is led globally by the WFP and is one of 11 clusters that identify key humanitarian sectors during emergencies. Requests for information would filter through the cluster, which would already have established partners it could call on for in-country coordinators, drone pilots and data analysts as needed, and be responsible for the government permissions process.  If a request is deemed suitable for drone technology use, the cluster would then coordinate flights to avoid overlap.  . . .  “We hope by next year we are deploying drones not for the sake of deployment, but because there is a need and a gap … And that we have an established practice rather than an ad hoc situation; that is our goal,” Baqir said.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I see many obstacles to a positive resolution of this question:  1)  the cost of UAVs, 2) their limited payload capability, 3) that this question requires that they be used in a conflict zone, and 4) the requirement that they be used to "deliver aid"--presently they seem to be used only for damage assessment.
Really only updating to add this cool article about disappearing drones: https://slice.mit.edu/2017/11/06/drones-disappear-morse-corp/
Lowering considerably due to no recent news of organisations testing prototypes in the field.

See @shivadiva October 9 post and comments. Agree. Up-voted 1. Dropping % for the passage of time.

OFFTOPIC, yet related: In the spirit of adopting good ideas and techniques: I started to use GJO's forecasting format for my own personal stuff, in the good spirit of adopting this proven way of thinking after two years of learning by doing. The picture shows how it works in my computer. On the left, I have my personal forecasting question with the answer options A and B. In the middle, each row is an individual forecasting entry/update with dates. On the right, there are the probabilities in columns - A and B, per each row. https://s1.postimg.org/4sd4ciltbz/Clipboard023.png The “smarter” part of this setup are is the calendar. The forecast really is set to last until 1.3.2018 and the next forecast update is due on 18.12.2017 (in 70 days), reminding me not to forget about it and only to care about it once or twice every two months. From the last two years, I noticed that forecasts over 90 days only need to be updated about three, four times for a reasonable accurate picture. Reading the news, of course, remains the A and O regardless. What's missing is the Brier calculation, the benchmark crowd and the nice chat with you, of course. The Brier calculation can be done by exporting the entries to Excel and compute it there. There will be no benchmark and no big chatter. The fun part, however, remains that I apply this to matters closer to home, like: Housing: How much rent will an apartment in London cost on 31.12.2017 (12:00 CEST)? Will Germany hold federal elections for the Bundestag before 1 September 2021? or  What percentile (men) will my recovery heart rate be after the step test on 31 December 2017?

Comments: Bureaucracy..... naturally ,:^(   The technology is actually proven/operational, just waiting on the will. See also @AB747 September 29 post and comments. Up-voted 1. Adjusting forecast.
Digital Trends, September 28, 'DRONES CAN HELP WHEN DISASTER STRIKES, BUT ONLY WHEN THEY’RE ALLOWED TO': https://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/rescue-drones-hurricane-flood-disaster-relief/
Clips from article:
"Bots vs. bureaucrats
Following Hurricane Harvey, a collective of drone experts known as Humanitarian Drones used DroneDeploy to map damaged areas for the National Guard and the city of Houston. The group, formed solely to help with Harvey relief efforts, was initially tasked with helping the American Red Cross with post-Harvey aid — but its efforts were hampered by an unnatural force that often wreaks havoc on innovative ideas: bureaucracy.
“Don’t attach yourself to any one organization. We learned that with the Red Cross,” Humanitarian Drones member Ty Audronis told Digital Trends. “I’m sure they’re a fantastic organization, but they’re really big, and with a big organization comes a lot of bureaucracy and a lot of opinions. So, while they were figuring out whether or not they wanted us to help them, we should’ve been out helping other people at the same time instead of waiting on them.” "But these gripes may soon be things of the past. Norwegian drone maker Griff Aviation is making a fleet of drones capable of carrying upwards of 1,100 pounds — enough to lift a few people at one time. The company’s Griff Saviour almost seems made for hurricane rescue efforts, with its 440-pound lift capacity, water-resistant motors, and ability to deploy lifesaving equipment. The drone’s price tag — a whopping $250,000 – will likely make this bird prohibitively expensive for hobbyists and local governments alike.
On top of that, ADS-B location reporting tech might soon make its way into consumer UAVs. DJI’s Matrice 200 drone boasts the company’s own ADS-B transponder, called Airsense. If more companies follow suit, air traffic controllers would be able to track drones just like they track full-sized aircraft — and more importantly, help them avoid collisions during disaster relief efforts."
Comments: General Atomics already has a modified Predator with heavy-lift capability available to aid groups. "THE WAY FORWARD
Clearly, we need a better system in place. Days after Harvey touched down in Texas, FAA Administrator Michael Huerta predicted “the hurricane response will be looked back upon as a landmark in the evolution of drone usage in this country.”
His prediction is already coming true. The American Red Cross recently announced it will fly a drone for the first time to assess damages as part of its new drone program for disasters. Similarly, the Air National Guard recently deployed military drones normally used for combat to help survey disaster areas. So while the ball might have been dropped as far as using UAVs to help out during the 2017 hurricane season, we’re already learning from our mistakes.
As soon as lawmakers and UAV manufacturers embrace the legitimate lifesaving potential of drones, the world will be a safer place." Related:
New [drone] website launched a couple of days ago: Drone Major: http://dronemajor.net/

Dropping forecast due to 3 months remaining.  “Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Development Cooperation, Alexander De Croo, announced that Belgium will double its investment in humanitarian innovation next year. One of the innovative projects that Belgium is investing in, together with the WFP, is a programme for the development of humanitarian drones. “The WFP’s humanitarian drones are a good example of the humanitarian innovation we need. By investing more into new technologies, we make humanitarian aid more efficient. Especially when more money is needed each year for humanitarian crisis situations, this is an investment that makes a difference,” Minister De Croo said” (https://reliefweb.int/report/world/belgium-doubles-its-investment-humanitarian-innovation)
Check out @tsm link to UN article.  Talk about investing in projects for next year put’s this out of our timeline and also shows that organisations are only just publicly acknowledging the benefits of using them. 
However, still the possibility of an organisation using drones for medical reasons in conflict zones, e.g. world's biggest cholera crisis in Yemen. And choosing not to publicly announce it for security reasons.
Dropping because I feel like this would have happened by now or at least been announced.

It occurs to me that "an unmanned aerial vehicle" could in certain circles include a parachute or glider full of supplies dropped from a standard aircraft.  Presumably that isn't what anybody is interested in, so I guess I am just being a nuisance.  Disregard this traffic.

Zip Line is only delivering aid to Rwanda and Tanzania. Rwanda is definitely not a conflicting zone and won't become one, but a UN peacekeeper was killed in Tanzania recently. I should keeo an eye on things to see if things escalate, but even if it does, Zip Line might withdraw to avoid risking it's equipment. Drones can be used to drop grenades and bombs on soldiers (ISIS has done this), so drones in the wrong place at the wrong time can be shot down.

tsm has some great comments about the state of the technology so far. It looks like this is a relatively new idea which is still being tested and improved. There are already drones delivering aid, but not to conflict zones, and if aid workers are still arguing about whether this is a good idea and whether more testing is necessary, then it'll be a while before anyone is willing to risk a drone in an area where people can shoot it down. No-one wants to donate money to a charity which takes needless risks. We'll see lots of drones in peaceful places before they're sent to combat zones.
Some entrepreneur needing to whitewash their name (Mark Zuckerberg?) will do it because they can and for the publicity. It's cheaper. Yemen could be on the list also

It is very likeley, especially for natural disaster zones or zones hit by a serious disease or no access to the infrastructure. It is also likely that individuals are already using it for an organization without mentioning it.

NBC News, September 9, 'Hurricanes Show Why Drones Are the Future of Disaster Relief - When it comes to assessing damage and spotting people in distress, drones may be hard to beat': https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/hurricanes-show-why-drones-are-future-disaster-relief-ncna799961
Clip from NBC article:
"Murphy said she was pleased that drones are becoming an integral part of disaster relief efforts — and surprised that it took so long. "If you’d told me in 2005, having seen their clear value after Katrina, that it would be 10 years before they were adopted by all of the emergency management systems, I would have laughed," she said. "I’m really excited that this may be the time where everybody sees that it’s time to get them in the hands of emergency managers."  Defence Web, September 8, 'Feature: UAVs in UN service': http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=49169&catid=35&Itemid=107
Clips from Defence article:
"For UNICEF and other humanitarian and development agencies, he sees drone technology making a difference in three ways. 
Firstly, drones can leapfrog broken infrastructure in places where developed transportation networks or roads do not exist, carrying low-weight supplies. 
Second, UAVs can be used for remote sensing, such as gathering imagery and data in the wake of natural disasters like mudslides to locate where the damage is and where affected people are.
“I believe this technology will go through a few years of regulatory difficulty but will eventually become so ubiquitous and simple that it’s like a version of the cell phones you have,” Fabian said.
He also sees drones extending Wi-Fi connectivity, from sky to ground, providing refugee camps and schools with access to the Internet.
Although UNICEF’s use of drones has been limited to date, the agency is exploring ways to scale up the use of UAVs in its operations." Comments: Impediment reemphasized: Protocols for use. 
"Some UN peacekeeping missions, such as those in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Mali and the Central African Republic (CAR), have deployed unarmed surveillance UAVs to improve security for civilians.
"Drone technology can be a double-edged sword with UN human rights experts speaking out against lethal use of drones. 
“Hardware itself does not violate human rights. It is the people behind the hardware,” Fabian said stressing the need to “make sure any technology we bring in or work on falls within the framing of rights-based documents,” such as the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
UNICEF has a set of guiding principles for innovation, including elements such as designing with the end-user.
For drone applications to spread further the UN has to have a strong role in advocating the technology and ensuring policy is shared with different governments Fabian said. 
Additionally, governments have to clearly define why they need drones and what specifically they will be used for, while also building up national infrastructure to support their use."  Incremental downward adjustment due to IFP time constraint.

Had no plans to forecast here, but an item came across my screen and reminded me of this question so ... oh well.  MSF drone trial - but non-conflict and taking samples from the community to outside (wrong direction, not aid):  "In the remote communities outside Kerema town in Papua New Guinea, periods of heavy rain caused an unpaved access road to turn to deep clay mud. Without any other method of safe access, Doctors Without Borders trialed the use of small quadcopter drones to transport lab samples from patients with suspected tuberculosis back to Kerema general hospital. "  (https://donate.doctorswithoutborders.org/innovations - scroll down to drones section) Suspect that will first go to medical supplies in a non-conflict area and may stall there for some time, though perhaps use in an area that later is defined as a conflict zone will occur.

Dropping forecast: I have been looking out for updates on the Windhorse Pouncer drone. “Windhorse is currently testing concept demonstrators and is looking to build several full prototypes over the summer. The company is aiming for full flight tests before the end of 2017, with Pouncers ready for certification in early July 2018, if all goes well.”
“We will initially be launching Mark-II glider variants without the motor, which can be operated from transport aircraft in large volumes to help large-scale operations, Forrester said.” 
(http://insideunmannedsystems.com/urgent-supplies-air/)  The Mark-II glider is launched from transport aircraft, according to Windhorse’s conflict zone scenario (https://www.windhorse.aero/section.php/11/1/scenarios) - so they will be dependent on another organization to be able to do this (could be an IGO) . Seems unlikely that full flight tests would include conflict zone testing for the foreseeable future, given that they are currently testing concept demonstrators, real-world testing would carry very high risk at this stage.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Going to start dropping on this question, with only three months to go I haven't heard anything to suggest anyone is seriously looking into using drones like this right now.
I'm just not seeing this. Lots of tests to deliver humanitarian aid  by UAVs but not in conflict zones. Will move farther away from consensus with time.

CNN, November 17, 2016, 'Predator tries new role: Humanitarian': http://money.cnn.com/2016/11/15/news/companies/predator-turns-humanitarian-angel-one/index.html
Clips from article:
"General Atomics hasn't signed up any aid organizations yet, but it's hoping the aircraft can be used to assist groups like USAID or Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders). It anticipates either donating the plane's operations or providing them at cost.
Using the Angel One, which can be flown remotely, can be less expensive and also less dangerous than sending supplies out with a manned aircraft like Lockheed Martin (LMT)'s C-130 airlifter." "Angel One can carry 8,500 pounds of daily food rations for 3,400 people on three, three-hour missions each day, the company estimates. The aircraft is capable of flying up to 16 hours each day." Comments: Agree with @AB747 August 20 post and comments. Up-vote 1. This robust platform is available now and General Atomics will donate or provide at cost. What's not to like about that? Test it. Dropping incrementally solely on time constraints.

-5%; i actually don't believe that it would be a valid option, but it takes just one organisation to disagree with that assessment and try it out in any conflict zone. so i am hesitant to reduce my forecast further. (main reasons why i do not believe that his will happen soon: drones cannot transport enough items & possible headlines like 'lost drone of organisation x used by armed militia to spot troop movement/civilian hiding places' are not the best marketing you could think of if your work relies on donations as do most humanitarian organisations)

Just noticed that owing to the way the Q is worded,  if the UN does this it won't count as a Yes.  The UN is an intergovernmental organization, not an non-governmental  or "intra-governmental" organization.  On the other hand, if the US National Security Council did this, it would be a Yes, since that is indeed an intra-governmental outfit, although not an intergovermental one.   The way language works, or used to, is that words have meanings, or used to.  One supposes that the writers meant "inter-" rather than "intra-" unless it's meant to be a trick question, so I'm not letting this affect my number.
I think y'all are a bunch of dreamers with your 90-100% probability on this question. But I do really want it to be true.
I think the issue will be finding out about it.

Maintaining forecast: 
NGO’s and intra-governmental agencies use drones to map displaced populations. With inaccessible communities in northeast Nigeria vulnerable to famine and the cholera epidemic in Yemen, the agencies may be more inclined to use drones to deliver aid in order to prevent situations from worsening. Lack of funding may make the use of drones cost prohibitive, but the technology needs testing at some point.
Moving into fall and winter months, weather will play a major factor in UAV launch timetables (accelerate or delay) going forward. Affirming forecast.

Comments: Yemen
PBS News Hour, August 4, 'PHOTOS: How aid groups are tackling Yemen’s cholera outbreak': http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/photos-aid-groups-tackling-yemens-cholera-outbreak/
Clips from PBS article:
"How widespread is the outbreak? Yemen’s Health Ministry has reported about 408,600 suspected cases of cholera and 1,885 deaths in the current outbreak, which began in October 2016. The country has seen a surge since April of 5,000 cases reported each day.
U.N. agency leaders who recently visited the Arab country are calling it the “world’s worst cholera outbreak in the midst of the world’s largest humanitarian crisis.” Medicins Sans Frontiers, update August 3, 'Yemen: crisis update – July 2017': http://www.msf.org/en/article/yemen-crisis-update--july-2017 African Business, August 3, 'Malawi’s drone corridor challenges scepticism towards UAVs': http://africanbusinessmagazine.com/sectors/development/malawis-drone-corridor-challenges-scepticism-towards-uavs/
Clips from AB article:
The project will run for at least a year. Thus far, 12 companies, NGOs and universities have applied to fly test missions in the corridor, which covers an area of 5,000km2 and contains 301 schools and 486 health service points.
Tests will explore using UAVs for imaging during disasters, connectivity in problematic terrain and transportation of medical supplies and vaccines. “We believe that this technology will transform healthcare, putting anyone within reach of the medicine they need,” said a spokesperson from robotics company Zipline.
UcanDrone, a Greek firm, is using the corridor to test a single UAV that can transport supplies, perform surveying missions and provide internet access. Swedish company GLOBHE, in collaboration with IBM, is testing drones with artificial intelligence to act as early warning systems in emergencies.
“It will be an interesting testing period over the next few months, but we are quite positive in terms of the opportunities this will create in Malawi and beyond,” said Helena Samsioe, CEO of GLOBHE." Affirming forecast.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

The drones that many hobbyists use have low-capacity and are most likely to be used for low-weight, high-value items such as drugs.  A 1-pound package is pushing it. A 4-ounce package maybe, depending upon the distance. Such drones often use an electric battery, and are limited to 30 minutes or so of flight, meaning an overall range of 1 mile or so. That is not likely to be used for humanitarian purposes, unless we are talking gold or medicine. As drones "mature," fueled motors like by gasoline are beginning to be used for propulsion. Such motors have much more energy for longer-range missions with larger payloads. Drones are difficult targets, especially at night.  They can fly via GPS, and get to difficult locations with relatively low exposure to being hit by weapons such as rifle fire. They do have the advantage of being able to land with pin-point accuracy, and the ability to bring small packages back to the launch area. Only if it is necessary to feed a very small group would I expect drones to be used to deliver much of any payload. My knee-jerk reaction to delivery of a serious amount of "humanitarian aid" would be the use of parachute air drops  from (generally-small) piloted aircraft. "Gut opinion:" the use of small drones for humanitarian purposes is unlikely at this stage of the game.  "Humanitarian" assistance generally involves bulky and  heavy items.
~~~~~
 COMMENT:  These are the thoughts of a hobbyist.

Africa’s first humanitarian drone testing corridor launched in Malawi by Government and UNICEF The Government of Malawi and UNICEF today launched an air corridor to test potential humanitarian use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), also known as drones. The corridor is the first in Africa and one of the first globally with a focus on humanitarian and development use. It is centred on Kasungu Aerodrome, in central Malawi, with a 40km radius (80km diameter) and is designed to provide a controlled platform for the private sector, universities and other partners to explore how UAVs can be used to help deliver services that will benefit communities. “Malawi has over the years proved to be a leader in innovation and it is this openness to innovation that has led to the establishment of Africa’s first drones testing corridor here in Malawi,” said Malawi’s Minister of Transport and Public Works, Jappie Mhango. “We have already used drones as part of our flood response and we can see the potential for further uses, such as transportation of medical supplies, which could transform lives in remote rural communities.” The Humanitarian UAV Testing Corridor will facilitate testing in three main areas:
1. Imagery – generating and analyzing aerial images for development and during humanitarian crises, including for situation monitoring in floods and earthquakes;
2. Connectivity – exploring the possibility for UAVs to extend Wi-Fi or cellphone signals across difficult terrain, particularly in emergencies;
3. Transport – delivery of small low weight supplies such as emergency medical supplies, vaccines and samples for laboratory diagnosis, including for HIV testing. “This humanitarian drone testing corridor can significantly improve our efficiency and ability to deliver services to the world's most vulnerable children,” said UNICEF Office of Global Innovation Principal Adviser Christopher Fabian. “The success of these trials will depend on working in new ways with the private sector, government and local entrepreneurs and engineers who can ensure that technologies deliver appropriate solutions for the people who need them the most.”
https://www.unicef.org/media/media_96560.html Perhaps needless to say, but Malawi is a conflict zone. Mozambique’s Invisible Civil War The government says everything’s fine. But that’s not what we heard from its victims.

http://www.herald.co.zw/malawi-tanzania-border-dispute-flares-up-again/ drones have already been successfully deployed to disaster situations. Following the earthquake of 16 April in Ecuador, GlobalMedic used several UAV teams to examine unsafe buildings and provide photo maps of affected areas.

The trip inspired Wyrobek to co-found Zipline, a California-based company that ferries supplies to remote health care sites using specialized, insulated drones. As stated in the FSD report, the use of drones still has strong military connotations, and until a solid framework can be developed in which UAVs can be reliably identified as non-military, I think it is unlikely that they will be used to provide humanitarian aid in a conflict zone.

There are still technical kinks about delivering stuff by drone, mostly but not all to do with safety--what happens if it encounters unexpected conditions or otherwise drops out of the sky.  Not to put too fine a point on it, these considerations matter less in a place where armed conflict has produced a humanitarian crisis; those folks are already at sufficently high risk that having a UAV fall on them is practically rounding error.  You and I should not think like that, but we are for the most part not drone manufacturers anxious to test our kit.

Clips from article:
"Charity Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), which has set up cholera treatment centres in the country, also fears the outbreak will spiral out of control.
"Before the outbreak, the health system was already overstretched and people's health needs were already huge," says Ghassan Abou Chaar, MSF's head of mission in Yemen.
"To bring the outbreak under control, it won't be enough simply to treat those people who reach medical facilities. We also need to address the source of the disease, by improving water and sanitation and working in communities to prevent new cases."

Save the Children said all sides in the conflict should end restrictions on the import of aid immediately."

Humanitarian organizations have started to use UAVs, including in Haiti and the Philippines, for data collection and information tasks that include real time information and situation mon- itoring, public information and advocacy, search and rescue, and mapping.
• The most likely humanitarian application in the area of delivery and logistics would be delivery of small medical supplies, such as vaccines.
• The use of UAVs raises serious practical and ethical issues that humanitarian organizations must address through transparency, community engagement, and guidelines for privacy and data security.
• Developing safeguards and guidance for the use of UAVs in conflict settings, whether strictly for humanitarian purposes or for protection and human rights work, will be a significant chal- lenge. The humanitarian system should therefore focus on uses in natural disasters and early recovery settings.
• To tap into the growing interest in UAVs, particularly in technical communities, humanitarian organizations should engage in networks that promote good practices and guidance, and that can serve as a source of surge capacity.
• Despite their potential to enhance humanitarian operations, more research and evidence is needed to identify the comparative advantages of using UAVs. More research is needed on in- tegrating aerial observation and data collection into needs and damage assessments, search and rescue, and other humanitarian functions.
https://docs.unocha.org/sites/dms/Documents/Unmanned%20Aerial%20Vehicles%20in%20Humanitarian%20Response%20OCHA%20July%202014.pdf
_________________________________
COMMENTS:  The usefulness of the UAV is undeniable; Interest is building in the use of UAVs to assist in search and rescue, particularly when equipped with infrared, or other specialty cameras. For example, the European Union is fund- ing ICARUS, a research project to develop unmanned search and rescue tools to assist human teams. To be useful, the UAVs and trained sta  must be available within 24-48 hours of a sudden-onset disaster. In addition these technical approaches must be integrated into the protocols for rescue teams, agreements for importing dis- aster response equipment, the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group (INSARAG) guidelines and other areas of policy.
BUT there are challenges to an effective use of UAV. The biggest challenges to expanding the use of UAVs are legal and regulatory. In the OECD, most countries are just developing legal guidance for the commercial or civilian use of UAVs. Many countries in the global South, particularly those with large humanitarian caseloads, may have very little regulation at all. 
In the U.S., commercial unmanned aerial system (UAS) licenses were granted on a case-by-case basis, subject to approval by the FAA.27 Similar restrictions exist in the UK and EU.28 Many countries where humanitarians are working do not yet have legal frameworks, meaning that use of UAVs will probably need to be cleared on an ad hoc basis with local and national authorities. To ensure long-term acceptance of these tools it will be critical that humanitarians comply with all host country regulations and develop appropriate agreements with regulators. A particular issue is interference with traditional air tra ic: in many countries it is illegal to fly anything within 5km of a commercial airport. As humanitar- ian operations o en center around emergency airports and logistics hubs, these restrictions are of particular concern.
Other than the above there are also issues of:
Ethical procurement and partnerships
Privacy and data protection
Transparency, informed consent and community engagement
*** Ironing out all these issues takes time. While, like the consensus I do think it will be the thing of the future, this Q may close before all issues are solved.

Clips from Chronicle article:
"The UPS Foundation President and UPS Chief Diversity and Inclusion Officer Eduardo Martinez said preparing, responding and helping communities recover from natural disasters and other humanitarian crises occurring around the world are tragedies where the foundation and UPS can help save lives by contributing its logistics expertise, healthcare solutions and global reach.
UPS reported among the initiatives, the foundation partnered with Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, and Zipline, a California-based robotics company, to leverage drones to deliver life-saving blood, medicines and vaccines to remote communities, beginning with Rwanda. The foundation also is working with UNICEF on the rollout of Visibility for Vaccines (ViVa), a cutting-edge tracking system that enables early identification of potential stock outs and overstocks of vaccines. ViVa will help global communities ensure supply of life-saving vaccines by providing alerts of critical shortage and overstock situations and allowing for corrective actions." Yahoo, April 23, '9 incredible ways we're using drones for social good': https://www.yahoo.com/tech/9-incredible-ways-apos-using-145141619.html
Clips from Yahoo article:
"1. Humanitarian aid
Unmanned aerial vehicles have a proven track record of being useful in disaster relief efforts. Drones helped aid organizations identify areas of need in the Philippines following Typhoon Haiyan in 2013, locate mines displaced by the massive Balkan floods in 2014, and document the aftermath of the Nepal earthquake in 2015.
Now, companies are testing to see how drones can regularly deliver humanitarian aid, rather than just inform NGOs where to go.
San Francisco-based Otherlab recently launched the world's most advanced industrial paper airplanes to do just that. The APSARA glider is made of biodegradable materials, and can carry more than two pounds of lifesaving supplies, such as blood and vaccines. When dropped out of a cargo airplane, the drones' interior tech helps them steer themselves in a spiral motion to a designated location using GPS and autopilot. It can land within a 33-foot radius of its intended destination.
Another project wants survivors of natural disasters to get their aid and eat it, too. Windhorse Aerospace created an inexpensive prototype called Pouncer, whose wings are packed with food. The protective covers surrounding the food can double as shelter, while the the drone's plywood frame can be used as firewood.
It can be extremely difficult (and even dangerous) for aid workers to get to people in hard-to-reach areas, whether it's a rural region of a developing nation, or a country plagued by conflict. But if you cut humans out of the equation, the seemingly insurmountable task gets a little easier." Affirming forecast.

This is a helpful article from December 2016 which highlights the issues that other forecasters and myself have brought up: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/04/us-uk-explore-possibility-aid-airdrops-syria-drones These were talks conducted between the US and UK governments in relation to the crisis in Syria; “the US and UK have been holding talks to explore ways to airdrop food and medical supplies to eastern Aleppo and other besieged populations in Syria”. These included parachute drops, drone flights and edible drones. 
Discussions had been ongoing for months and had been “mired in disagreements between government agencies, the reluctance of the military to get involved and concern among officials that flying in aid without permission from the Damascus regime and its allies could hamper conventional humanitarian deliveries”  Types of humanitarian aid deliveries that had been discussed at meetings included:
1) Convoys with diplomats from western and Arab countries, though this would still need to go through the same approvals as UN convoys and would essentially suffer the same fate of not getting through. 
2) “Traditional military air drops would have to be carried out at such high altitude, to avoid anti-aircraft missiles, that they would be worse than useless”  “Commercially made drones discussed at the UK embassy meeting could carry payloads of 2 - 50kg. For use in conflict zones, like Syria, they could be programmed to randomise flight paths, altering altitude and direction in unpredictable ways so they would be harder to shoot down. The guidance circuitry could also self-destruct in the event of a crash, so it could not be used as a weapon if it fell into the wrong hands."  There was “strong interest from some parts of the US and UK governments in a large-scale drone airlift, but there are still significant obstacles”. For example, in Syria - “most drone flights would need to take off from Turkey and would need Ankara’s permission”  The main issue is getting permission for drone flights, and if its done without permission there is a risk that it will make the whole situation worse. “US and UK military had pointed out that any relief flights made without Syrian Government or Russian permission risk causing an international incident that could spiral out of control.” I have only decreased my forecast slightly, mainly due to the time period left, but I still think this is very likely to happen, as mentioned in this article: “technology is only just being field tested”. It is almost certain that more field tests will be carried out this year, especially if governments want to avoid the level of desperation reached with what happened in Syria in places like Yemen.

I see the key constraints of this forecast as (1) the intended payload, (2) the operating organization, and (3) the target area. (1) The intended payload of 'humanitarian aid' means a UAV will need to be big and powerful enough to carry the weight of a package worthy of being delivered at a distance. There are a variety of commercial drones available that could carry small to medium payloads, such as medical supplies, as has been mentioned by others here. However, most UAVs on the market are not designed/suitable for more than camerawork or very light cargo. Small doses of supplies that take several hours to deliver, while lifesaving, might not be the most efficient way to assist those in a conflict zone. Prospective financiers of such an enterprise might be tempted by more efficient ways to spend their money. For example, General Atomics' Angel One has been available to deliver large quantities of aid since at least November 2016, but no NGO has put up the money to use the vehicle. Further, heavier aid such as food or water quickly narrows the field of capable UAV systems. (2) Military organizations around the world are best positioned to have the type of UAV technology required to transport the quantities of aid that would make a difference in a conflict zone. The question specifies the user be an NGO, several of which are indeed exploring use of UAVs for aid purposes. However, these efforts are not plentiful. In situations where airdrop is deemed the best method for delivering humanitarian aid, large military cargo aircraft are used. Also, while airdropping cargo is expensive, military budgets are generally better able to absorb such costs, vis a vis an NGO. (3) Delivery to a conflict zone necessitates long flight distances and high altitudes if the UAV is to avoid being intercepted, which is a risk where aggressors may want to capture an expensive piece of equipment they can re-purpose, maintain the political pressure created by a subjected civilian population, etc. Most organizations that are exploring UAV-delivered cargo are not designing their vehicles to these constraints. For example, Zipline and Matternet are targeted at covering the "last mile" of rural deliveries in Africa; Amazon, UPS, etc are planning on (at least initially) peaceful metropolitan service areas; other services in disaster relief situations are focused on high frequency deliveries over shorter distances (see National link). Summary: NGO UAVs are likely to target a niche outside of high volume airdrops, which are currently the purview of military aircraft. As such, the payload needs to be sufficiently high value in order to make the cost/benefit of the required flight profile worthwhile. The technology is advancing, and its costs will continue to decrease, but not as rapidly as if there were more players in this arena designing to the unique constraints of operating in a conflict zone (as opposed to the plethora of hobby UAV options). However, the severe need to be served and the positive publicity that would come from an NGO delivering aid to a conflict zone continue to keep the idea in play. The number of "conflict zones" also factor in to this forecast. I think this will happen eventually, but probably not this year. I will reevaluate towards the end of the summer.

When I wrote about medical drones a few weeks ago, I interviewed the spokesman of Zipline. He gave me these responses: What are Zipline’s plans for the next years?
Justin Hamilton: "We plan to expand across Rwanda, Africa and (to dream big) the whole wide world. Also, we want to move beyond just blood delivery and include other essential and lifesaving medicines. In the next few years, we expect to be able to make on-demand deliveries to community health workers who travel from village to village (as long as that worker has a smartphone)." What are the biggest challenges in terms of technology?
Justin: "Technology is actually not our biggest challenge. We’ve built an autonomous aircraft from scratch that can deliver medical products to locations 75km away. But creating the vehicles are only a fraction of our work. Zipline has set up a national drone delivery service that integrates a public health supply chain and built the infrastructure and equipment necessary to do a 50-150 flights per day." Conclusion: They can already do it but need direct request from an international organization and/or the affected country. Source:
http://medicalfuturist.com/medical-drones/
Great use of drones and it will be tested soon.

I think its inevitable UAV will be used to deliver aid in a conflict zone, for the sole purpose that more field testing needs to be done, without which they won’t know if it will be a viable solution in the future. But I don’t think it will become public knowledge on the day that it happens.  For low flying drones its pretty easy to track the general direction they are coming from so I don’t see how using a drone to transport high value/low volume cargo will not compromise the safety of those piloting/launching the drone and those that the delivery is intended for. The main issue is that there are no regulations that are universally agreed. As an example, Afghanistan only permits drones to fly in daylight hours (uavsystemsinternational.com) and flying in Nigeria requires a government permit (ncaa.gov.ng).  There is no doubt that the technology is there for cargo drones and case studies show that it works. For example, UPS successfully delivered a package, launching the drone from the top of the UPS van on Friday 24th February 2017, the case study given by @Raahul_Kumar on Zipline in Rwanda and Medicins Sans Frontièrs/ Matternet collaboration on delivering medicine supplies in rural parts of Papua New Guinea in 2014 (drones.fsd.ch/en/drones-in-humanitarian-action). Only one case study on cargo drones used in the “Drones in humanitarian action: A guide to the use of airborne system in humanitarian crises” was located in a conflict zone. The Syrian Airlift Project was set up in 2014 with the sole purpose of delivering humanitarian aid from Turkey to besieged civilians in Syria - the project dissolved in December 2015 due to lack of sponsorship. However, one of the main issues that the project came up against was legislation, which the aforementioned guide also raised. I think the concept of using drones to deliver aid is a brilliant idea, given the lives it could help and save - but using drones in a conflict zone is not comparable to using them for disaster relief. The issue with running an operation like Zipline in a conflict zone - where they have 15 drones making 150 deliveries each day - is that by having 15 drones flying in what eventually would be a repetitive flight path would draw too much attention from hostile groups/organisations.
Unlike a lot of questions, this is one for which the outcome can be controlled. Does anyone else want to contribute to an organization that will do this?
the technology is there. The only thing missing is some neglect for national borders and protocol to help those in need.
I'm actually surprised it hasn't already happened.

The technology is there, but both NGO's and technology companies will want to time its use so that it gains maximum attention. The real question therefore is whether there will be a suitable disaster this year. It needs to be:
-Quite close to heavily populated areas so that lots of TV crews are around. Also close enough to infrastructure to enable UAV's to be flown out.
-An event that gains a lot of sudden attention and lots of disaster. Good weather, so flooding is out of the question. Basically has to be an earthquake, but not of the 9-Richter scale which desolates everything around. More like 7 Richter.
-A low-intensity conflict that makes it difficult for convoys to get across but no anti-aircraft fire.
-What is the probability of an earthquake that causes more than 1000 deaths in an unstable area? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_21st-century_earthquakes
2001 Gujarat, 2003 Bam, Iran, 2004 Pakistan, 2007 Kashmir, 2008 Pakistan, 2010 Afghanistan, 2011 Myanmar, 2013 Pakistan. 8 in 16 years, or 50%. Since there is pressure to deliver, I would nudge this up by a bit to 60%.
Yes it is already an viable option
Seems more of an issue of identifying the event when it happens.
seems pretty easy, no impediments to it other than a dictator shooting it down

Heck, why not? The technology is here and now!
The Cipher Brief, February 12, 'The New Technology of Humanitarian Assistance': https://www.thecipherbrief.com/article/tech/new-technology-humanitarian-assistance-1092
Clip from Cipher article:
"Potential advances in artificial intelligence (AI), however, could allow swarms of small drones to slip by air defense systems to individually deliver small packages of cargo—possibly even create impromptu networks for Wi-Fi and establish phone signal availability. Chow asserts that “as costs come down and AI-driven avionics accelerate in power, flotillas of drones over vulnerable regions can provide constant coverage for early detection and rapid response to humanitarian crises.” Artificially intelligent drones could also address major impediments to post-conflict reconstruction, such as landmine removal to enable locals to return to an agricultural economy while mitigating indiscriminate casualties largely affecting children. The Mine Kafon Drone seeks to autonomously map a designated area, detect the positioning of mines via GPS and then safely detonate them at a pace unmatched by even skilled personnel." Delivery by drone reduces the risks.

Zipline Raises $25 Million to Expand Drone Delivery of Medical Supplies into Rwanda
by Alan Perlman on November 25, 2016	 San Francisco-based company Zipline International has raised $25 million in Series B funding to expand its work delivering medical supplies via drones into Africa. We wrote earlier this year about Zipline testing their services in Africa and it looks like those tests have proved successful, if this new round of funding is any indicator. The company is partnering with the government of Rwanda to deliver much needed medical supplies to remote clinics in the East African nation.
http://uavcoach.com/zipline-raises-25-million-for-work-in-africa/ The World's First National Drone Delivery Service Just Launched In Rwanda Zipline's flying bots aren't delivering products from Amazon or burritos. They're delivering life-saving medicine to remote hospitals.
https://www.fastcoexist.com/3064623/the-worlds-first-national-drone-delivery-service-just-launched-in-rwanda

The first in its kind, this survey measures perceptions of the use of drones in humanitarian action.  The  Swiss  Foundation  for  Mine  Action  (FSD)  undertook  the  survey  between  15  November 2015 and 15 January 2016.  A  majority  of  survey  respondents  expressed  confidence  that  drones  have  the  potential  to  strengthen humanitarian work, and that drones can greatly enhance the speed and quality of localized needs assessments, while a significant minority viewed the use of drones in humanitarian  work  unfavourably.  Importantly  only  roughly  one  in  ten  respondents  had  actual  experience with drones in humanitarian settings.
http://drones.fsd.ch/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Drones-in-Humanitarian-Acion-Survey-Analysis-FINAL21.pdf Unarmed drones have already been used by the United Nations in the Goma region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo to help peacekeepers locate and avoid civilians in potential lines of fire. A company called Skycap has also successfully tested disaster relief drones to provide aid in areas that become inaccessible. The Irish Times reports that there are efforts underway to use drones to speed up “search-and-rescue operations for migrants in the Mediterranean.” The potential of drones in humanitarian aid is huge. According to CNBC, a company called Zipline has used drones to save millions of lives in the East African country of Rwanda. The company “delivers essential medical supplies…. within minutes.” Zipline claims that with drones, delivery times can be cut from 15 hours to 15 minutes. Therefore HIV, malaria and tuberculosis treatment and medicine can reach people where and when they need it. Ensuring that people have access to medical supplies will also prevent death from childbirth in remote areas.
http://www.borgenmagazine.com/drones-in-humanitarian-aid/
